answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
Since 2009 The city of Albany, Oregon had had all checks and the entire general ledger available online and updated daily in the Albany Dashboard.
http://dashboard.cityofalbany.net/Dashboard/Pages/Report.aspx?ItemPath=/Albany_Dashboard

answers.author: Rebecca Eby
answers.text:
While I am no longer with Sedgwick County, Kansas, I know the County places their checkbook online: https://ssc.sedgwickcounty.org/checkbook/default.aspx , as well as all County Grants and County Contracts: http://www.sedgwickcounty.org/finance/reports.asp.  The Contracts and Grants are in very user friendly Sharepoint SQL databases that allow visitors to short by category, department, etc.  The Checkbook is in a different program.  If you have specific questions staff in the Division of Finance should be able to help you.

If you have specific questions staff in the Division of Finance should be able to help you.

answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
Hi Sallie, 
In an article from PM Magazine, The Time for Transparency is Now, there is a discussion of using online checkbooks to increase transparency and you can learn about the City of Austin's experience using such a tool. 
http://webapps.icma.org/pm/9505/public/cover.cfm?title=The%20Time%20for%20Transparency%20Is%20Now%20%20&subtitle=&author=Kevin%20Lahner
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

author: Sallie Ann Burnett
text: A member would like to know about your experience with cities and counties that have an online checkbook.
title: Checkbook online
